pages.raw_output:
<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 186, 171, 201]]<|/det|>
# PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 206, 332, 222]]<|/det|>
Paper 1 Multiple Choice (Core)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 247, 590, 291]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: Multiple Choice Answer Sheet Soft clean eraser Soft pencil (type B or HB recommended)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 312, 388, 328]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 342, 237, 357]]<|/det|>
Write in soft pencil.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 357, 504, 372]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 372, 892, 401]]<|/det|>
Write your name, centre number and candidate number on the Answer Sheet in the spaces provided unless this has been done for you.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 400, 384, 415]]<|/det|>
DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 429, 892, 459]]<|/det|>
There are forty questions on this paper. Answer all questions. For each question there are four possible answers A, B, C and D.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 459, 890, 475]]<|/det|>
Choose the one you consider correct and record your choice in soft pencil on the separate Answer Sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 488, 556, 504]]<|/det|>
Read the instructions on the Answer Sheet very carefully.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 517, 765, 533]]<|/det|>
Each correct answer will score one mark. A mark will not be deducted for a wrong answer.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 533, 467, 548]]<|/det|>
Any rough working should be done in this booklet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 549, 359, 564]]<|/det|>
Electronic calculators may be used.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 564, 630, 579]]<|/det|>
Take the weight of \(1.0\mathrm{kg}\) to be \(10\mathrm{N}\) (acceleration of free fall \(= 10\mathrm{m / s}^2\) ).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 96, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 72, 601, 89]]<|/det|>
A student uses a ruler to find the volume of water in a tank.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 102, 437, 120]]<|/det|>
She measures the lengths EF and FG.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[292, 129, 700, 288]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 303, 500, 321]]<|/det|>
What other length does she need to measure?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 332, 128, 350]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[139, 332, 166, 350]]<|/det|>
FJ

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 332, 298, 350]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[303, 332, 346, 350]]<|/det|>
FK

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[448, 332, 468, 350]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[473, 332, 510, 350]]<|/det|>
HI

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[636, 332, 656, 350]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[660, 332, 675, 350]]<|/det|>
IJ

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 377, 96, 395]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 377, 789, 395]]<|/det|>
An object begins to fall close to the Earth's surface. Air resistance can be ignored.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 406, 603, 425]]<|/det|>
Which statement about the object's acceleration is correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 435, 133, 453]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 435, 390, 453]]<|/det|>
The acceleration is constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 460, 131, 479]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 460, 526, 479]]<|/det|>
The acceleration decreases as the body falls.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 486, 131, 505]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 486, 520, 504]]<|/det|>
The acceleration increases as the body falls.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 513, 131, 532]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 513, 356, 532]]<|/det|>
The acceleration is zero.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 558, 96, 575]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 556, 618, 575]]<|/det|>
A car travels at an average speed of \(60\mathrm{km / h}\) for 15 minutes.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 587, 467, 604]]<|/det|>
How far does the car travel in 15 minutes?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 615, 131, 632]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[143, 615, 160, 632]]<|/det|>
4.0 km

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 615, 298, 632]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[303, 615, 371, 632]]<|/det|>
15 km

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[448, 615, 468, 632]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[473, 615, 548, 632]]<|/det|>
240 km

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 615, 636, 632]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[648, 615, 715, 632]]<|/det|>
900 km

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 660, 96, 678]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 660, 873, 678]]<|/det|>
Which equation shows the relationship between the weight \(W\) and the mass \(m\) of an object?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 694, 133, 714]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 692, 220, 714]]<|/det|>
\(W = \frac{m}{g}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 735, 133, 752]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 735, 222, 752]]<|/det|>
\(W = mg\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 762, 133, 780]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 762, 242, 780]]<|/det|>
\(W = m + g\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 795, 133, 814]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 794, 217, 814]]<|/det|>
\(W = \frac{g}{m}\)

<label>19</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 485, 922, 536]]<|/det|>
A beaker contains some cold water. A purple crystal is placed on the bottom of the beaker. The beaker is gently heated beneath the crystal. The crystal dissolves in the water. The colour spreads, as shown in the diagram.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[437, 543, 562, 710]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 724, 625, 743]]<|/det|>
Three students each make a statement about the experiment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 755, 707, 774]]<|/det|>
Student 1 says the purple water is less dense than the rest of the water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 784, 680, 802]]<|/det|>
Student 2 says the purple water is warmer than the rest of the water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 813, 920, 846]]<|/det|>
Student 3 says all of the water will eventually get heated, even though water is a poor conductor of thermal energy.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 858, 351, 875]]<|/det|>
Which students are correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 885, 138, 904]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 885, 740, 904]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 462, 106, 481]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 462, 546, 482]]<|/det|> An iron nuclide is represented by the symbol shown. <|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[468, 492, 531, 521]]<|/det|> \[\frac{56}{26}\mathrm{Fe}\] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 536, 662, 556]]<|/det|> Which statements about a nucleus of this iron nuclide are correct? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 567, 510, 586]]<|/det|> 1 The nucleus contains 56 neutrons. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 593, 445, 612]]<|/det|> 2 The nucleon number is 30. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 619, 435, 637]]<|/det|> 3 The proton number is 26. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 650, 138, 668]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 650, 688, 668]]<|/det|> 1 and 2 only B 1 and 3 only C 2 and 3 only D 3 only

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 106, 91]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 737, 92]]<|/det|> Three types of radiation that can cause ionisation are \(\alpha\)-, \(\beta\)- and \(\gamma\)-radiation. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 102, 707, 122]]<|/det|> Which row identifies the least and the most ionising of these radiations? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 133, 390, 277]]<|/det|>
least ionisingmost ionising
A\(\alpha\)\(\beta\)
B\(\alpha\)\(\gamma\)
C\(\gamma\)\(\beta\)
D\(\gamma\)\(\alpha\)
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 304, 104, 323]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 304, 680, 323]]<|/det|> Why are some radioactive sources stored in boxes made from lead? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 333, 134, 351]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 333, 599, 351]]<|/det|> Lead absorbs emissions from the radioactive sources. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 359, 134, 378]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 359, 574, 378]]<|/det|> Lead decreases the half-life of radioactive sources. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 386, 133, 405]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 386, 567, 403]]<|/det|> Lead increases the half-life of radioactive sources. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 411, 133, 429]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 411, 584, 429]]<|/det|> Lead repels emissions from the radioactive sources.
